topic.title: Overview
topic.shortdesc: A high-level overview of Couchbase Server's core features.

section.title: Core Features
section.p: These can be summarized as follows:

li.p: Data: Couchbase Server stores data as items. Each item consists of a key, by which the item is referenced; and an associated value, which must be either a binary or a JSON document. The maximum size for an individual item is 20MB.

Buckets, Memory, and Storage: Items are stored in Buckets, the assigned names of which are referenced by applications attempting to access items. Buckets are of different types: some are kept only in memory, others both in memory and on disk.

Services and Indexes: Services can be deployed to support different forms of data-access: for example, the Data Service allows items to be retrieved by their key; while the Query Service allows them to be retrieved on a basis of queries, designed in the N1QL query-language. Services are also provided to support data-analysis and automated data-update.
The Index and Search services provide different forms of index: indexes support potentially complex queries and searches, and enhance their performance.

Clusters and Availability: A single node running Couchbase Server is considered a cluster of one node. As successive nodes are initialized, each can be configured to join the existing cluster. Individual services can be configured to run across multiple cluster-nodes, allowing the handling of high-priority workloads to be scaled appropriately.

Across the nodes of each cluster, Couchbase data is evenly distributed and replicated: nodes can be removed, and node-failure handled, without data-loss. Data can be selected for replication across clusters residing in different data centers, to ensure high availability.

section.p: These elements are described in detail throughout the pages in this section.
